diagrams.descriptionHtml: Emergency Escape and Rescue Opening: An operable exterior window, door or similar device that provides for a means of escape and access for rescue in the event of an emergency.

diagrams.title: Emergency Egress: Doors and Area Wells
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Emergency Escape and Rescue Opening: An operable exterior window, door or similar device that provides for a means of escape and access for rescue in the event of an emergency.

diagrams.title: Emergency Windows Under Decks and Porches
diagrams.descriptionHtml: According to the Residential Code, an emergency escape and rescue opening is an operable exterior window, door, or similar device that provides a means of escape and access for rescue in the event of an emergency. When located under a deck or porch, the opening shall be fully openable and provide a path not less than 36 inches in height and open into a yard or court.

children.displayTitle: R310.2 Emergency Escape and Rescue Openings

children.body:
Emergency and escape rescue openings shall have a net clear opening of not less than 5.7 square feet (0.530 m2). The net clear opening dimensions required by this section shall be obtained by the normal operation of the emergency escape and rescue opening from the inside. The net clear height of the opening shall be not less than 24 inches (610 mm) and the net clear width shall be not less than 20 inches (508 mm).
Exception: Grade floor openings or below-grade openings shall have a net clear opening area of not less than 5 square feet (0.465 m2).

diagrams.title: Replacement Windows
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Replacement windows are windows that have been developed in a manner that allows a contractor to not have to remove the exterior materials of the home in order to install the window. Typically they are measured to fit in an existing window opening and will only replace the actual window itself.

diagrams.title: Emergency Egress: Min. Dimensions
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Emergency Escape and Rescue Opening: An operable exterior window, door or similar device that provides for a means of escape and access for rescue in the event of an emergency. Emergency escape and rescue openings are intended as a direct means of egress or rescue from sleeping rooms and basements when the primary exit is blocked.

Buildings classified as Group R-2 that have stories with one exit are required to be equipped throughout with an NFPA 13 or 13R automatic sprinkler system and provided with emergency escape and rescue openings in accordance with Section 1030. Emergency escape and rescue opening requirements also apply to R-3 and R-4 Occupancies.

children.body: Where a window is provided as the emergency escape and rescue opening, it shall have a sill height of not more than 44 inches (1118 mm) above the floor; where the sill height is below grade, it shall be provided with a window well in accordance with Section 310.2.3.

diagrams.title: Replacement Windows
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Replacement windows are windows that have been developed in a manner that allows a contractor to not have to remove the exterior materials of the home in order to install the window. Typically they are measured to fit in an existing window opening and will only replace the actual window itself.

diagrams.title: Emergency Egress: Min. Dimensions
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Emergency Escape and Rescue Opening: An operable exterior window, door or similar device that provides for a means of escape and access for rescue in the event of an emergency. Emergency escape and rescue openings are intended as a direct means of egress or rescue from sleeping rooms and basements when the primary exit is blocked.

Buildings classified as Group R-2 that have stories with one exit are required to be equipped throughout with an NFPA 13 or 13R automatic sprinkler system and provided with emergency escape and rescue openings in accordance with Section 1030. Emergency escape and rescue opening requirements also apply to R-3 and R-4 Occupancies.

children.body:
The horizontal area of the window well shall be not less than 9 square feet (0.9 m2), with a horizontal projection and width of not less than 36 inches (914 mm). The area of the window well shall allow the emergency escape and rescue opening to be fully opened.
Exception: The ladder or steps required by Section 310.2.3.1 shall be permitted to encroach not more than 6 inches (152 mm) into the required dimensions of the window well.

diagrams.title: Emergency Egress: Window Wells
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Emergency Escape and Rescue Opening: An operable exterior window, door or similar device that provides for a means of escape and access for rescue in the event of an emergency.

children.body: Window wells with a vertical depth greater than 44 inches (1118 mm) shall be equipped with a permanently affixed ladder or steps usable with the window in the fully open position. Ladders or steps required by this section shall not be required to comply with Section 311.7. Ladders or rungs shall have an inside width of not less than 12 inches (305 mm), shall project not less than 3 inches (76 mm) from the wall and shall be spaced not more than 18 inches (457 mm) on center vertically for the full height of the window well.

diagrams.title: Emergency Egress: Window Wells
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Emergency Escape and Rescue Opening: An operable exterior window, door or similar device that provides for a means of escape and access for rescue in the event of an emergency.

children.body:
Window wells shall be designed for proper drainage by connecting to the building's foundation drainage system required by Section 405.1 or by an approved alternative method.
Exception: A drainage system for window wells is not required where the foundation is on well-drained soil or sand-gravel mixture soils in accordance with the Unified Soil Classification System, Group I Soils, as detailed in Table 405.1.

diagrams.title: Emergency Egress: Window Wells
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Emergency Escape and Rescue Opening: An operable exterior window, door or similar device that provides for a means of escape and access for rescue in the event of an emergency.

diagrams.title: Residential Basement Walls
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Basement walls retaining soil are called "Foundation Walls" in the code. A "retaining wall" is defined by the Residential Code as a wall not laterally supported at the top, that resists lateral soil load and other imposed loads, such as a site retaining wall.

children.body: Emergency escape and rescue openings installed under decks and porches shall be fully openable and provide a path not less than 36 inches (914 mm) in height to a yard or court.

diagrams.title: Emergency Windows Under Decks and Porches
diagrams.descriptionHtml: According to the Residential Code, an emergency escape and rescue opening is an operable exterior window, door, or similar device that provides a means of escape and access for rescue in the event of an emergency. When located under a deck or porch, the opening shall be fully openable and provide a path not less than 36 inches in height and open into a yard or court.

children.displayTitle: R310.2.4 Emergency Escape and Rescue Openings Under Decks and Porches
children.titleText: Emergency Escape and Rescue Openings Under Decks and Porches

children.body:
Replacement windows installed in buildings meeting the scope of this code shall be exempt from the maximum sill height requirements of Section 310.2.2 and the requirements of Section 310.2.1, provided that the replacement window meets the following conditions:
  1. The replacement window is the manufacturer's largest standard size window that will fit within the existing frame or existing rough opening. The replacement window is of the same operating style as the existing window or a style that provides for an equal or greater window opening area than the existing window.
  2. The replacement window is not part of a change of occupancy.
Exception: Replacement windows installed in accordance with Section 113.5.1 shall not be required to comply with Section 310.2.1.

diagrams.title: Replacement Windows
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Replacement windows are windows that have been developed in a manner that allows a contractor to not have to remove the exterior materials of the home in order to install the window. Typically they are measured to fit in an existing window opening and will only replace the actual window itself.

children.body: Where a door is provided as the required emergency escape and rescue opening, it shall be a side-hinged door or a slider. Where the opening is below the adjacent grade, it shall be provided with an area well.

diagrams.title: Emergency Egress: Doors and Area Wells
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Emergency Escape and Rescue Opening: An operable exterior window, door or similar device that provides for a means of escape and access for rescue in the event of an emergency.

children.displayTitle: R310.3 Emergency Escape and Rescue Doors

children.body: The minimum net clear height opening for any door that serves as an emergency and escape rescue opening shall be in accordance with Section 310.2.1.
Area wells shall have a width of not less than 36 inches (914 mm). The area well shall be sized to allow the emergency escape and rescue door to be fully opened.

diagrams.title: Emergency Egress: Doors and Area Wells
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Emergency Escape and Rescue Opening: An operable exterior window, door or similar device that provides for a means of escape and access for rescue in the event of an emergency.

children.body: Area wells with a vertical depth greater than 44 inches (1118 mm) shall be equipped with a permanently affixed ladder or steps usable with the door in the fully open position. Ladders or steps required by this section shall not be required to comply with Section 311.7. Ladders or rungs shall have an inside width of not less than 12 inches (305 mm), shall project not less than 3 inches (76 mm) from the wall and shall be spaced not more than 18 inches (457 mm) on center vertically for the full height of the exterior stairwell.

Area wells shall be designed for proper drainage by connecting to the building's foundation drainage system required by Section 405.1 or by an approved alternative method.
Exception: A drainage system for area wells is not required where the foundation is on well-drained soil or sand-gravel mixture soils in accordance with the Unified Soil Classification System, Group I Soils, as detailed in Table 405.1.

Where bars, grilles, covers, screens or similar devices are placed over emergency escape and rescue openings, area wells, or window wells, the minimum net clear opening size shall comply with Sections 310.2.1 through 310.2.3, and such devices shall be releasable or removable from the inside without the use of a key, tool, special knowledge or force greater than that required for the normal operation of the escape and rescue opening.

diagrams.title: Bulkhead Enclosures
diagrams.descriptionHtml: A bulkhead enclosure provides a secure and weather-resistant exit from the basement to the outside of a building. The stairways serving bulkhead enclosures are not part of the required primary means of escape. The maximum height from the basement finished floor level to the finished ground level adjacent to the stairway must not exceed 8 ft.

children.displayTitle: R310.4 Bars, Grilles, Covers and Screens

children.body: Where dwelling additions contain sleeping rooms, an emergency escape and rescue opening shall be provided in each new sleeping room.

An emergency escape and rescue opening is not required where existing basements undergo alterations or repairs.
Exception: New sleeping rooms created in an existing basement shall be provided with emergency escape and rescue openings in accordance with Section 310.1.

diagrams.title: Basement Alterations
diagrams.descriptionHtml: An emergency escape and rescue opening is not required where existing basements undergo alterations or repairs, unless a sleeping room is being added to a basement area.

children.displayTitle: R310.6 Alterations or Repairs of Existing Basements
children.titleText: Alterations or Repairs of Existing Basements

diagrams.title: Floor Elevation at Required Egress Doors (8-1/4”)
Tread and Landing Slopes
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Interior treads and landings are typically constructed level. In some locations it may be necessary to slope the tread or landing surface to provide for drainage or to address other unique conditions and construction tolerances. Stairway tread and landing walking surfaces may be sloped up to one unit vertical in 48 units horizontal, or 2% maximum.

diagrams.title: Egress Door Requirements
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Each dwelling unit is required to have one Egress Door. The door is required to be a hinged door with a clear opening of 32" with the door at 90°. The minimum egress door opening height is 78" from the top of the threshold to the bottom of the head stop. Other doors exit access doors in the dwelling unit are not required to meet the minimum egress door dimensions. All exit and exit access doors in a dwelling are required to have hardware that enables occupants to readily open the door from inside without the use of a key, special knowledge or effort.

diagrams.title: Vertical Egress
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Habitable levels and habitable attic levels that do not have an egress door shall be provided with vertical egress to an exit. Where required, the vertical egress shall be by a ramp in compliance with R311.8 or by a stairway in compliance with R311.7.

diagrams.title: Stairway Landings: Non Square or Rectangle
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The area and dimensions of a landing may be reduced to one quarter of a circle with a radius not less than the width of the stairway served. The center of the circle must be concentric with the center of the walkline at the landing.

children.body: Dwellings shall be provided with a means of egress in accordance with this section. The means of egress shall provide a continuous and unobstructed path of vertical and horizontal egress travel from all portions of the dwelling to the required egress door without requiring travel through a garage. The required egress door shall open directly into a public way or to a yard or court that opens to a public way.

diagrams.title: Means of Egress Pathways
diagrams.descriptionHtml: From any location within a dwelling an unobstructed and continuous path horizontal and vertical path shall be provided to the required egress door. The egress path of travel shall not pass through the garage to reach the required egress door. The required egress door is required to open directly to a public way or to a yard or court that opens to a public way.

children.body: Not less than one egress door shall be provided for each dwelling unit. The egress door shall be side-hinged, and shall provide a clear width of not less than 32 inches (813 mm) where measured between the face of the door and the stop, with the door open 90 degrees (1.57 rad). The clear height of the door opening shall be not less than 78 inches (1981 mm) in height measured from the top of the threshold to the bottom of the stop. Other doors shall not be required to comply with these minimum dimensions. Egress doors shall be readily openable from inside the dwelling without the use of a key or special knowledge or effort.

diagrams.title: Doors: Min. Required Clear Opening Width
diagrams.descriptionHtml: A door has to be at least 32" minimum clear width to provide enough space for people with mobility impairments or those who use mobility aids (such as wheelchairs, walkers or crutches) to pass through comfortably. Wider door widths are required for Group I-2 when movement of beds is required. Other exceptions also apply in Section 1010.1.1. Door widths should be sufficient to allow safe passage in the clear space between the face of the door to the edge of the door stop.

diagrams.title: Floor Elevation at Required Egress Doors (8-1/4”)
Egress Door Requirements
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Each dwelling unit is required to have one Egress Door. The door is required to be a hinged door with a clear opening of 32" with the door at 90°. The minimum egress door opening height is 78" from the top of the threshold to the bottom of the head stop. Other doors exit access doors in the dwelling unit are not required to meet the minimum egress door dimensions. All exit and exit access doors in a dwelling are required to have hardware that enables occupants to readily open the door from inside without the use of a key, special knowledge or effort.

diagrams.title: Vertical Egress
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Habitable levels and habitable attic levels that do not have an egress door shall be provided with vertical egress to an exit. Where required, the vertical egress shall be by a ramp in compliance with R311.8 or by a stairway in compliance with R311.7.

children.body: Garages shall be served by at least one side-hinged door not less than 2 feet 6 inches (760 mm) in width and 6 feet 8 inches (2032 mm) in height. Such door located between a dwelling and an attached garage shall be acceptable for meeting this requirement.

There shall be a landing or floor on each side of each exterior door. The width of each landing shall be not less than the door served. Landings shall have a dimension of not less than 36 inches (914 mm) measured in the direction of travel. The slope at exterior landings shall not exceed 1/4 unit vertical in 12 units horizontal (2 percent).
Exception: Exterior balconies less than 60 square feet (5.6 m2) and only accessed from a door are permitted to have a landing that is less than 36 inches (914 mm) measured in the direction of travel.

diagrams.title: Landings at Balcony Doors: Exception
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Balconies of limited size are not required to have a full depth landing/floor area normally required for an exterior doorway.

children.displayTitle: R311.3 Floors and Landings at Exterior Doors
children.titleText: Floors and Landings at Exterior Doors

children.body:
Landings or finished floors at the required egress door shall be not more than 11/2 inches (38 mm) lower than the top of the threshold.
Exception: The landing or floor on the exterior side shall be not more than 81/4 -inches (209 mm) below the top of the threshold provided that the door does not swing over the landing or floor.
Where exterior landings or floors serving the required egress door are not at grade, they shall be provided with access to grade by means of a ramp in accordance with Section 311.8 or a stairway in accordance with Section 311.7.

diagrams.title: Floor Elevation at Required Egress Doors (8-1/4”)

children.displayTitle: R311.3.1 Floor Elevations at the Required Egress Doors
children.titleText: Floor Elevations at the Required Egress Doors

children.body:
Doors other than the required egress door shall be provided with landings or floors not more than 81/4-inches (209 mm) below the top of the threshold.
Exception: A top landing is not required for the stairway located on the exterior side of the door, provided that the threshold of the door is not more than 30" above the adjacent grade and the door does not swing over the stairway.
children.displayTitle: R311.3.2 Floor Elevations at Other Exterior Doors
children.titleText: Floor Elevations at Other Exterior Doors

children.body: Storm and screen doors shall be permitted to swing over exterior stairs and landings.

diagrams.title: Floor Elevation at Required Egress Doors (8-1/4”)

children.body: Egress from habitable levels including habitable attics and basements that are not provided with an egress door in accordance with Section 311.2 shall be by a ramp in accordance with Section 311.8 or a stairway in accordance with Section 311.7.

diagrams.title: Emergency Egress: Basements
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Emergency Escape and Rescue Opening: An operable exterior window, door or similar device that provides for a means of escape and access for rescue in the event of an emergency. Emergency escape and rescue openings are intended as a direct means of egress or rescue from sleeping rooms and basements when the primary exit is blocked.

diagrams.title: Means of Egress Pathways
diagrams.descriptionHtml: From any location within a dwelling an unobstructed and continuous path horizontal and vertical path shall be provided to the required egress door. The egress path of travel shall not pass through the garage to reach the required egress door. The required egress door is required to open directly to a public way or to a yard or court that opens to a public way.

diagrams.title: Vertical Egress
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Habitable levels and habitable attic levels that do not have an egress door shall be provided with vertical egress to an exit. Where required, the vertical egress shall be by a ramp in compliance with R311.8 or by a stairway in compliance with R311.7.

children.body: Exterior landings, decks, balconies, stairs and similar facilities shall be positively anchored to the primary structure to resist both vertical and lateral forces or shall be designed to be self-supporting. Attachment shall not be accomplished by use of toenails or nails subject to withdrawal.

diagrams.title: Guards:  Connection Requirements
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
ASCE 7 requires the 200 pound load to be placed in any direction at any point on the handrail or top rail to produce a maximum load effect. This would mean a load pulling on the rail inward would create a maximum tension on the bottom bolt, but a 200 pound force outward (typically associated with "falling" outward) would put the maximum tension on the top bolt.

However, the Residential Code, in Table R301.5, footnote d, states: "A single concentrated load applied in any direction at any point along the top. For a guard not required to serve as a handrail, the load need not be applied to the top element of the guard in a direction parallel to such element." This language does not seem to appear in ASCE 7 at this time.

Therefore, the designer should consider providing tension resisting hardware on both bolts, or consider an alternate design. Simply relying on the rim board would put the member into cross-grain bending, which has considerably lower strength than the beam itself.

diagrams.title: Emergency Windows Under Decks and Porches
diagrams.descriptionHtml: According to the Residential Code, an emergency escape and rescue opening is an operable exterior window, door, or similar device that provides a means of escape and access for rescue in the event of an emergency. When located under a deck or porch, the opening shall be fully openable and provide a path not less than 36 inches in height and open into a yard or court.

diagrams.title: Landings at Balcony Doors: Exception
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Balconies of limited size are not required to have a full depth landing/floor area normally required for an exterior doorway.

children.displayTitle: R311.5 Landing, Deck, Balcony and Stair Construction and Attachment
children.titleText: Landing, Deck, Balcony and Stair Construction and Attachment

children.body: The width of a hallway shall be not less than 3 feet (914 mm).

diagrams.title: Min. Area and Dimensions (Residential)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The code ensures that adequate room is provided in habitable rooms and spaces. Section 304.1 calls for a minimum floor area of 70 sf in habitable rooms. To ensure that no habitable room dimension is too small section 304.2 calls for minimum room dimension of 7' in any horizontal dimension. The minimum habitable room dimension and area requirements do not apply to kitchens. The minimum means of egress width for hallways in residences is 36".

diagrams.title: Type I Handrail Profile (Res.)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Type I handrails are either circular with a cross section that has an outside diameter between 1-1/4" to 2" maximum. When the handrail is not circular, then it needs to have a perimeter that is between 4" to 6-1/4" maximum with a cross section that is not greater than 2-1/4". The edges of non-circular handrail can have a radius of 0.01" minimum.

diagrams.title: Handrail Continuity - Exception
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Handrail continuity is important for various reasons related to safety, accessibility, and compliance with building regulations. Firstly, a continuous handrail maximizes safety by providing continuous support for individuals navigating staircases and ramps, reducing the risk of slips and falls. This is especially beneficial for individuals who may have mobility issues, such as older adults or individuals with certain disabilities. Newel posts at a turn in the flight with winders, at landings or over the lowest tread are permitted to interrupt the continuity of the handrail. A volute, turnout or starting easing shall be permitted to terminate over the lowest tread as well.

diagrams.title: Handrail Continuity
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Handrail continuity is important for various reasons related to safety, accessibility, and compliance with building regulations. Firstly, a continuous handrail maximizes safety by providing continuous support for individuals navigating staircases and ramps, reducing the risk of slips and falls. This is especially beneficial for individuals who may have mobility issues, such as older adults or individuals with certain disabilities. Handrails' continuation without interruption by newel posts or other obstructions, also facilitates quicker and safer evacuation during an emergency.

diagrams.title: Type II Handrail Profile
diagrams.descriptionHtml: A Type 2 handrail is one that is larger than the graspable perimeter of a Type 1 handrail. In this condition, handrails with a perimeter greater than 6-1/4 inches are required to provide a graspable finger recess area on both sides of the profile. The Stair Manufacturers Association funded a study that determined that a pinch grip could provide graspable handrail. This was added to the Residential Code in 2001 and the Building Code for multifamily residential in 2009.

diagrams.title: Residential Guards
diagrams.descriptionHtml: GUARD. A building component or a system of building components located near the open sides of elevated walking surfaces that minimizes the possibility of a fall from the walking surface to the lower level.

diagrams.title: Example: Floor Opening - Stairway With Landing
Spiral Stairways and Treads (Residential)
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Stairway, Spiral: A stairway with a plan view of closed circular form and uniform section-shaped treads radiating from a minimum-diameter circle.

Section R311.7.10.1 applies to spiral stairways and defines the allowable dimensions of the stairway. The minimum stairway width required is 26". Unlike other stairway types the handrails are not allowed to project into the minimum clear width of a spiral stairways. The code also limits the walkline radius of spiral stairs to 24-1/2" maximum. The allowed tread depth for spiral stairways is measured at the walkline and must be 6-3/4" or larger. All treads within a spiral stairway must be the same dimensions. The maximum allowable riser height for spiral stairways is 9-1/2". The minimum headroom allowed within the stairway is 6'-6" and usually occurs where the upper landing projects over the stairway.

diagrams.title: Glazing Next to Stairs and Ramps (IRC)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Glazing adjacent to stairs and ramps shall be considered to be in a hazardous location and required safety glazing materials. Safety glazing materials, including but not limited to tempered glass, laminated glass, wire glass or rigid plastic, are used in hazardous locations where the potential for human impact can lead to serious injuries.

diagrams.title: Ship's Ladders (Residential)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Ship's ladders may not be used as a required means of egress. A ship's ladder may be provided in addition to a compliant required means of egress. There is an exception for spaces such as lofts, mezzanines and other similar areas less than or equal to 200 gross square feet that do not contain a kitchen or a bathroom that allows for a ship's ladder to be an element of the means of egress.

diagrams.title: Handrail Height
diagrams.descriptionHtml: A handrail is required on at least one side of all flights of stairs exceeding 3 risers. Handrail height along flights of stairs is measured from the imaginary plane or planes defined by the stairway's tread nosing. The code calls for handrails to be from 34 to 38 inches in height. Though not specifically noted in the code, handrail height should be consistent along each flight of stairs. The code allows for the rail height to exceed 38" at continuous transitions, typically called "goosenecks", that take place at between flights of stairs, winder treads, and where the handrail transitions from a stair handrail to a guard. Over the lowest tread, the code also allows for the handrail height to be lower than 34" or taller than 38" for a volute, turnout or starting easing.

diagrams.title: Alternating Tread Devices
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Alternating tread devices may not be used as a required means of egress. An alternating tread device may be provided in addition to a compliant required means of egress. There is an exception for spaces such as lofts, mezzanines and other similar areas less than or equal to 200 gross square feet that do not contain a kitchen or a bathroom that allows an alternating tread device to be an element of the means of egress.

diagrams.title: Stairway Width and Handrail Projections (RC)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Residential stairways are permitted to have a handrail on only one side of the stairway in the residential code. Minimum widths vary depending on how many handrails are provided, and the location of the width measurement per R311.7.1. The amount of distance a handrail may project into the stairway is limited by R311.7.8.2.

diagrams.title: Bulkhead Enclosures
diagrams.descriptionHtml: A bulkhead enclosure provides a secure and weather-resistant exit from the basement to the outside of a building. The stairways serving bulkhead enclosures are not part of the required primary means of escape. The maximum height from the basement finished floor level to the finished ground level adjacent to the stairway must not exceed 8 ft.

diagrams.title: Stairway Headroom & Vert. Rise - RC (OH)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Stairways require a minimum amount of headroom height. When placing stairways on a plan, always be sure to check if the stair when viewed in section, with the required rise and run of the treads, won't conflict with the floor above as as person comes up or down the stairs. Ways to fix this in the field can be undesirable aesthetically or expensive.

diagrams.title: Stair Walkline
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The location of the walkline at winder treads and landings is defined in the code. The walkline is parallel to the direction of travel. The walkline is located 12" from the inside face of the stair's clear width on the inside side of the turn. Where the stairway is "S" shaped the walkline will change sides of the stairway such that it is always 12" from the inside of the turn.

diagrams.title: Tread and Landing Slopes
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Interior treads and landings are typically constructed level. In some locations it may be necessary to slope the tread or landing surface to provide for drainage or to address other unique conditions and construction tolerances. Stairway tread and landing walking surfaces may be sloped up to one unit vertical in 48 units horizontal, or 2% maximum.

diagrams.title: Vertical Egress
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Habitable levels and habitable attic levels that do not have an egress door shall be provided with vertical egress to an exit. Where required, the vertical egress shall be by a ramp in compliance with R311.8 or by a stairway in compliance with R311.7.

diagrams.title: Stairway Landings: Non Square or Rectangle
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The area and dimensions of a landing may be reduced to one quarter of a circle with a radius not less than the width of the stairway served. The center of the circle must be concentric with the center of the walkline at the landing.

children.body:
Stairways shall be not less than 36 inches (914 mm) in clear width at all points above the permitted handrail height and below the required headroom height. The clear width of stairways at and below the handrail height, including treads and landings, shall be not less than 311/2 inches (787 mm) where a handrail is installed on one side and 27 inches (698 mm) where handrails are installed on both sides.
Exception: The width of spiral stairways shall be in accordance with Section 311.7.10.1.

diagrams.title: Stairway Width and Handrail Projections (RC)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Residential stairways are permitted to have a handrail on only one side of the stairway in the residential code. Minimum widths vary depending on how many handrails are provided, and the location of the width measurement per R311.7.1. The amount of distance a handrail may project into the stairway is limited by R311.7.8.2.

children.body:
The headroom in stairways shall be not less than 6 feet 8 inches (2032 mm) measured vertically from the sloped line adjoining the tread nosing or from the floor surface of the landing or platform on that portion of the stairway.
Exceptions:
  1. Where the nosings of treads at the side of a flight extend under the edge of a floor opening through which the stair passes, the floor opening shall not project horizontally into the required headroom more than 4 3/4 inches (121 mm).
  2. The headroom for spiral stairways shall be in accordance with Section 311.7.10.1.

diagrams.title: Spiral Stairways and Treads (Residential)
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Stairway, Spiral: A stairway with a plan view of closed circular form and uniform section-shaped treads radiating from a minimum-diameter circle.

Section R311.7.10.1 applies to spiral stairways and defines the allowable dimensions of the stairway. The minimum stairway width required is 26". Unlike other stairway types the handrails are not allowed to project into the minimum clear width of a spiral stairways. The code also limits the walkline radius of spiral stairs to 24-1/2" maximum. The allowed tread depth for spiral stairways is measured at the walkline and must be 6-3/4" or larger. All treads within a spiral stairway must be the same dimensions. The maximum allowable riser height for spiral stairways is 9-1/2". The minimum headroom allowed within the stairway is 6'-6" and usually occurs where the upper landing projects over the stairway.

diagrams.title: Stairway Headroom & Vert. Rise - RC (OH)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Stairways require a minimum amount of headroom height. When placing stairways on a plan, always be sure to check if the stair when viewed in section, with the required rise and run of the treads, won't conflict with the floor above as as person comes up or down the stairs. Ways to fix this in the field can be undesirable aesthetically or expensive.

children.body: A flight of stairs shall not have a vertical rise larger than 148 1/2-inches (3772 mm) between floor levels or landings.

diagrams.title: Stairway Headroom & Vert. Rise - RC (OH)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Stairways require a minimum amount of headroom height. When placing stairways on a plan, always be sure to check if the stair when viewed in section, with the required rise and run of the treads, won't conflict with the floor above as as person comes up or down the stairs. Ways to fix this in the field can be undesirable aesthetically or expensive.

children.body: The walkline across winder treads and landings shall be concentric to the turn and parallel to the direction of travel entering and exiting the turn. The walkline shall be located 12 inches (305 mm) from the inside of the turn. The 12-inch (305 mm) dimension shall be measured from the widest point of the clear stair width at the walking surface. Where winders are adjacent within a flight, the point of the widest clear stair width of the adjacent winders shall be used.

diagrams.title: Stair Walkline
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The location of the walkline at winder treads and landings is defined in the code. The walkline is parallel to the direction of travel. The walkline is located 12" from the inside face of the stair's clear width on the inside side of the turn. Where the stairway is "S" shaped the walkline will change sides of the stairway such that it is always 12" from the inside of the turn.

children.body: Stair treads and risers shall meet the requirements of this section. For the purposes of this section, dimensions and dimensioned surfaces shall be exclusive of carpets, rugs or runners.

diagrams.title: Winder Treads (State Specific)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Winder treads are allowed only in one and two-family dwellings in most new construction. Proper width at the narrow end of the winder tread is necessary to prevent an almost vertical condition where the risers for multiple stair are in near alignment. In addition, at the location where the foot would typically land with ones shoulder is nearest the wall (the walkline), 9" is required. In the residential code, the walkline is considered 12" from the side of the stairway at the inner side of the winding stair.

children.body:
The riser height shall be not more than 8 1/4 -inches (209 mm). The riser shall be measured vertically between leading edges of the adjacent treads. The greatest riser height within any flight of stairs shall not exceed the smallest by more than 3/8 inch (9.5 mm). Risers shall be vertical or sloped from the underside of the nosing of the tread above at an angle not more than 30 degrees (0.51 rad) from the vertical. At open risers, openings located more than 30 inches (762 mm), as measured vertically, to the floor or grade below shall not permit the passage of a 4-inch-diameter (102 mm) sphere.
Exceptions:
  1. The opening between adjacent treads is not limited on spiral stairways.
  2. The riser height of spiral stairways shall be in accordance with Section 311.7.10.1.

The tread depth shall be not less than 9-inches (229 mm). The tread depth shall be measured horizontally between the vertical planes of the foremost projection of adjacent treads and at a right angle to the tread's leading edge. The greatest tread depth within any flight of stairs shall not exceed the smallest by more than 3/8 inch (9.5 mm).

Winder treads shall have a tread depth of not less than 9-inches (229 mm) measured between the vertical planes of the foremost projection of adjacent treads at the intersections with the walkline. Winder treads shall have a tread depth of not less than 6 inches (152 mm) at any point within the clear width of the stair. Within any flight of stairs, the largest winder tread depth at the walkline shall not exceed the smallest winder tread by more than 3/8 inch (9.5 mm). Consistently shaped winders at the walkline shall be allowed within the same flight of stairs as rectangular treads and shall not be required to be within 3/8 inch (9.5 mm) of the rectangular tread depth.
Exception: The tread depth at spiral stairways shall be in accordance with Section 311.7.10.1.

diagrams.title: Winder Treads (State Specific)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Winder treads are allowed only in one and two-family dwellings in most new construction. Proper width at the narrow end of the winder tread is necessary to prevent an almost vertical condition where the risers for multiple stair are in near alignment. In addition, at the location where the foot would typically land with ones shoulder is nearest the wall (the walkline), 9" is required. In the residential code, the walkline is considered 12" from the side of the stairway at the inner side of the winding stair.

diagrams.title: Stair Walkline
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The location of the walkline at winder treads and landings is defined in the code. The walkline is parallel to the direction of travel. The walkline is located 12" from the inside face of the stair's clear width on the inside side of the turn. Where the stairway is "S" shaped the walkline will change sides of the stairway such that it is always 12" from the inside of the turn.

children.body:
Nosings at treads, landings and floors of stairways shall have a radius of curvature at the nosing not greater than 9/16 inch (14 mm) or a bevel not greater than 1/2 inch (12.7 mm). A nosing projection not less than 3/4 inch (19 mm) and not more than 11/4 inches (32 mm) shall be provided on stairways. The greatest nosing projection shall not exceed the smallest nosing projection by more than 3/8-inch (9.5 mm) within a stairway.
Exception: A nosing projection is not required where the tread depth is not less than 11 inches (279 mm).
Plastic composite exterior stair treads shall comply with the provisions of this section and Section 507.2.2.
children.displayTitle: R311.7.5.4 Exterior Plastic Composite Stair Treads

children.body:
There shall be a floor or landing at the top and bottom of each stairway. The width perpendicular to the direction of travel shall be not less than the width of the flight served. For landings of shapes other than square or rectangular, the depth at the walk line and the total area shall be not less than that of a quarter circle with a radius equal to the required landing width. Where the stairway has a straight run, the depth in the direction of travel shall be not less than 36 inches (914 mm).
Exception: A floor or landing is not required at the top of an interior flight of stairs, including stairs in an enclosed garage, provided that a door does not swing over the stairs.

diagrams.title: Stairway Landings: Non Square or Rectangle
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The area and dimensions of a landing may be reduced to one quarter of a circle with a radius not less than the width of the stairway served. The center of the circle must be concentric with the center of the walkline at the landing.

children.body: The walking surface of treads and landings of stairways shall be sloped not steeper than one unit vertical in 48 inches horizontal (2-percent slope).

diagrams.title: Tread and Landing Slopes
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Interior treads and landings are typically constructed level. In some locations it may be necessary to slope the tread or landing surface to provide for drainage or to address other unique conditions and construction tolerances. Stairway tread and landing walking surfaces may be sloped up to one unit vertical in 48 units horizontal, or 2% maximum.

children.body: Handrails shall be provided on not less than one side of each flight of stairs with four or more risers.

diagrams.title: Type I Handrail Profile (Res.)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Type I handrails are either circular with a cross section that has an outside diameter between 1-1/4" to 2" maximum. When the handrail is not circular, then it needs to have a perimeter that is between 4" to 6-1/4" maximum with a cross section that is not greater than 2-1/4". The edges of non-circular handrail can have a radius of 0.01" minimum.

diagrams.title: Handrail Continuity - Exception
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Handrail continuity is important for various reasons related to safety, accessibility, and compliance with building regulations. Firstly, a continuous handrail maximizes safety by providing continuous support for individuals navigating staircases and ramps, reducing the risk of slips and falls. This is especially beneficial for individuals who may have mobility issues, such as older adults or individuals with certain disabilities. Newel posts at a turn in the flight with winders, at landings or over the lowest tread are permitted to interrupt the continuity of the handrail. A volute, turnout or starting easing shall be permitted to terminate over the lowest tread as well.

diagrams.title: Handrail Continuity
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Handrail continuity is important for various reasons related to safety, accessibility, and compliance with building regulations. Firstly, a continuous handrail maximizes safety by providing continuous support for individuals navigating staircases and ramps, reducing the risk of slips and falls. This is especially beneficial for individuals who may have mobility issues, such as older adults or individuals with certain disabilities. Handrails' continuation without interruption by newel posts or other obstructions, also facilitates quicker and safer evacuation during an emergency.

diagrams.title: Type II Handrail Profile
diagrams.descriptionHtml: A Type 2 handrail is one that is larger than the graspable perimeter of a Type 1 handrail. In this condition, handrails with a perimeter greater than 6-1/4 inches are required to provide a graspable finger recess area on both sides of the profile. The Stair Manufacturers Association funded a study that determined that a pinch grip could provide graspable handrail. This was added to the Residential Code in 2001 and the Building Code for multifamily residential in 2009.

diagrams.title: Ship's Ladders (Residential)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Ship's ladders may not be used as a required means of egress. A ship's ladder may be provided in addition to a compliant required means of egress. There is an exception for spaces such as lofts, mezzanines and other similar areas less than or equal to 200 gross square feet that do not contain a kitchen or a bathroom that allows for a ship's ladder to be an element of the means of egress.

diagrams.title: Handrail Height
diagrams.descriptionHtml: A handrail is required on at least one side of all flights of stairs exceeding 3 risers. Handrail height along flights of stairs is measured from the imaginary plane or planes defined by the stairway's tread nosing. The code calls for handrails to be from 34 to 38 inches in height. Though not specifically noted in the code, handrail height should be consistent along each flight of stairs. The code allows for the rail height to exceed 38" at continuous transitions, typically called "goosenecks", that take place at between flights of stairs, winder treads, and where the handrail transitions from a stair handrail to a guard. Over the lowest tread, the code also allows for the handrail height to be lower than 34" or taller than 38" for a volute, turnout or starting easing.

diagrams.title: Stairway Width and Handrail Projections (RC)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Residential stairways are permitted to have a handrail on only one side of the stairway in the residential code. Minimum widths vary depending on how many handrails are provided, and the location of the width measurement per R311.7.1. The amount of distance a handrail may project into the stairway is limited by R311.7.8.2.

children.body:
Handrail height, measured vertically from the sloped plane adjoining the tread nosing, or finish surface of ramp slope, shall be not less than 34 inches (864 mm) and not more than 38 inches (965 mm)

Exceptions:
  1. The use of a volute, turnout or starting easing shall be allowed over the lowest tread.
  2. Where handrail fittings or bendings are used to provide continuous transition between flights, transitions at winder treads, the transition from handrail to guard, or used at the start of a flight, the handrail height at the fittings or bendings shall be permitted to exceed 38 inches (965 mm).

diagrams.title: Handrail Height
diagrams.descriptionHtml: A handrail is required on at least one side of all flights of stairs exceeding 3 risers. Handrail height along flights of stairs is measured from the imaginary plane or planes defined by the stairway's tread nosing. The code calls for handrails to be from 34 to 38 inches in height. Though not specifically noted in the code, handrail height should be consistent along each flight of stairs. The code allows for the rail height to exceed 38" at continuous transitions, typically called "goosenecks", that take place at between flights of stairs, winder treads, and where the handrail transitions from a stair handrail to a guard. Over the lowest tread, the code also allows for the handrail height to be lower than 34" or taller than 38" for a volute, turnout or starting easing.

children.body:
Handrails shall not project more than 41/2 inches (114 mm) on either side of the stairway.
Exception: Where nosings of landings, floors or passing flights project into the stairway reducing the clearance at passing handrails, handrails shall project not more than 61/2 inches (165 mm) into the stairway, provided that the stair width and handrail clearance are not reduced to less than that required.

diagrams.title: Stairway Width and Handrail Projections (RC)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Residential stairways are permitted to have a handrail on only one side of the stairway in the residential code. Minimum widths vary depending on how many handrails are provided, and the location of the width measurement per R311.7.1. The amount of distance a handrail may project into the stairway is limited by R311.7.8.2.

children.body: Handrails adjacent to a wall shall have a space of not less than 1<sup>1</sup>/<sub>2</sub> inches (38 mm) between the wall and the handrails.

diagrams.title: Stairway Width and Handrail Projections (RC)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Residential stairways are permitted to have a handrail on only one side of the stairway in the residential code. Minimum widths vary depending on how many handrails are provided, and the location of the width measurement per R311.7.1. The amount of distance a handrail may project into the stairway is limited by R311.7.8.2.

children.body:
Handrails shall be continuous for the full length of the flight, from a point directly above the top riser of the flight to a point directly above the lowest riser of the flight. Handrail ends shall be returned or shall terminate in newel posts or safety terminals.

Exceptions:
  1. Handrail continuity shall be permitted to be interrupted by a newel post at a turn in a flight with winders, at a landing, or over the lowest tread.
  2. A volute, turnout or starting easing shall be allowed to terminate over the lowest tread.
  3. Two or more separate rails shall be considered continuous if the termination of the rails occurs over a single tread and positioned within 4 inches of each other. If the transition occurs between a wall mounted handrail and handrail/guardrail combination, the wall mounted handrail shall return into the wall.

diagrams.title: Handrail Continuity - Exception
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Handrail continuity is important for various reasons related to safety, accessibility, and compliance with building regulations. Firstly, a continuous handrail maximizes safety by providing continuous support for individuals navigating staircases and ramps, reducing the risk of slips and falls. This is especially beneficial for individuals who may have mobility issues, such as older adults or individuals with certain disabilities. Newel posts at a turn in the flight with winders, at landings or over the lowest tread are permitted to interrupt the continuity of the handrail. A volute, turnout or starting easing shall be permitted to terminate over the lowest tread as well.

diagrams.title: Handrail Continuity
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Handrail continuity is important for various reasons related to safety, accessibility, and compliance with building regulations. Firstly, a continuous handrail maximizes safety by providing continuous support for individuals navigating staircases and ramps, reducing the risk of slips and falls. This is especially beneficial for individuals who may have mobility issues, such as older adults or individuals with certain disabilities. Handrails' continuation without interruption by newel posts or other obstructions, also facilitates quicker and safer evacuation during an emergency.

children.body:
Required handrails shall be of one of the following types or provide equivalent graspability.
  1. Type I. Handrails with a circular cross section shall have an outside diameter of not less than 11/4 inches (32 mm) and not greater than 2 inches (51 mm). If the handrail is not circular, it shall have a perimeter of not less than 4 inches (102 mm) and not greater than 61/4 inches (160 mm) and a cross section of not more than 21/4 inches (57 mm). Edges shall have a radius of not less than 0.01 inch (0.25 mm).
  2. Type II. Handrails with a perimeter greater than 61/4 inches (160 mm) shall have a graspable finger recess area on both sides of the profile. The finger recess shall begin within 3/4 inch (19 mm) measured vertically from the tallest portion of the profile and have a depth of not less than 5/16 inch (8 mm) within 7/8 inch (22 mm) below the widest portion of the profile. This required depth shall continue for not less than 3/8 inch (10 mm) to a level that is not less than 13/4 inches (45 mm) below the tallest portion of the profile. The width of the handrail above the recess shall be not less than 11/4 inches (32 mm) and not more than 23/4 inches (70 mm). Edges shall have a radius of not less than 0.01 inch (0.25 mm).

diagrams.title: Type I Handrail Profile (Res.)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Type I handrails are either circular with a cross section that has an outside diameter between 1-1/4" to 2" maximum. When the handrail is not circular, then it needs to have a perimeter that is between 4" to 6-1/4" maximum with a cross section that is not greater than 2-1/4". The edges of non-circular handrail can have a radius of 0.01" minimum.

diagrams.title: Type II Handrail Profile
diagrams.descriptionHtml: A Type 2 handrail is one that is larger than the graspable perimeter of a Type 1 handrail. In this condition, handrails with a perimeter greater than 6-1/4 inches are required to provide a graspable finger recess area on both sides of the profile. The Stair Manufacturers Association funded a study that determined that a pinch grip could provide graspable handrail. This was added to the Residential Code in 2001 and the Building Code for multifamily residential in 2009.

diagrams.title: Handrails: Cross Section (Type I)
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
In the building code, two types of handrails are listed: type I and type II. The ADA Standards has a single handrail specification. Surface requirements and clearances facilitate a power grip along the length of handrails. Handrails can have circular or non-circular cross-sections, but must have rounded edges. The gripping surface and adjacent surfaces must be free of abrasive or sharp elements. Wall-mounted handrails with leading edges higher than 27" cannot protrude more than 41/2" into circulation paths (§307.2).

ADA Standards Advisory 505.6 Gripping Surface. People with disabilities, older people, and others benefit from continuous gripping surfaces that permit users to reach the fingers outward or downward to grasp the handrail, particularly as the user senses a loss of equilibrium or begins to fall.

children.body: Plastic composite exterior handrails shall comply with the requirements of Section 507.2.2.
Stairways shall be provided with illumination in accordance with Sections 303.7 and 303.8.

diagrams.title: Exterior Stair Illumination (RC)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Stairways require an illumination source to be used safely. Stairways to a basement would be those meeting the rise/run and other requirements of the stairway. Illumination would not be required at stairs covered by hinged bulkhead doors, where the height from the basement finished floor level to grade adjacent to the stairway is not more than 8 feet, per Section R311.7.10.2.

diagrams.title: Interior Stair Illumination (RC)
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
A foot-candle (fc) is a unit of illuminance, representing the amount of light that falls onto a surface. It is defined as one lumen per square foot. To visualize what one foot-candle of illuminance looks like, consider the following description:

Imagine a single candle lit in a completely dark room. If you were to measure the light falling on a one-square-foot surface situated one foot away from the candle (in direct line with the flame and without any obstructions), that would be approximately equivalent to one foot-candle of illuminance.

In practical terms, this is a rather low level of light, akin to the soft, dim light you might experience in a room illuminated only by candlelight. It's more than enough to make out shapes and some details, but it's much dimmer than the lighting levels we're used to in well-lit indoor spaces. To put it into perspective, a typical home living room in the evening with artificial light might range from 10 to 50 foot-candles, whereas an office lighting is typically brighter, often around 30 to 50 foot-candles.

children.body: Spiral stairways and bulkhead enclosure stairways shall comply with the requirements of Section 311.7 except as specified in Sections 311.7.10.1 and 311.7.10.2.

diagrams.title: Bulkhead Enclosures
diagrams.descriptionHtml: A bulkhead enclosure provides a secure and weather-resistant exit from the basement to the outside of a building. The stairways serving bulkhead enclosures are not part of the required primary means of escape. The maximum height from the basement finished floor level to the finished ground level adjacent to the stairway must not exceed 8 ft.

children.body: The clear width at and below the handrails at spiral stairways shall be not less than 26 inches (660 mm) and the walkline radius shall be not greater than 241/2 inches (622 mm). Each tread shall have a depth of no less than 63/4 inches (171 mm) at the walkline. Treads shall be identical, and the rise shall be not more than 91/2 inches (241 mm). Headroom shall be not less than 6 feet 6 inches (1982 mm).

diagrams.title: Spiral Stairways and Treads (Residential)
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Stairway, Spiral: A stairway with a plan view of closed circular form and uniform section-shaped treads radiating from a minimum-diameter circle.

Section R311.7.10.1 applies to spiral stairways and defines the allowable dimensions of the stairway. The minimum stairway width required is 26". Unlike other stairway types the handrails are not allowed to project into the minimum clear width of a spiral stairways. The code also limits the walkline radius of spiral stairs to 24-1/2" maximum. The allowed tread depth for spiral stairways is measured at the walkline and must be 6-3/4" or larger. All treads within a spiral stairway must be the same dimensions. The maximum allowable riser height for spiral stairways is 9-1/2". The minimum headroom allowed within the stairway is 6'-6" and usually occurs where the upper landing projects over the stairway.

diagrams.title: Stair Walkline
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The location of the walkline at winder treads and landings is defined in the code. The walkline is parallel to the direction of travel. The walkline is located 12" from the inside face of the stair's clear width on the inside side of the turn. Where the stairway is "S" shaped the walkline will change sides of the stairway such that it is always 12" from the inside of the turn.

children.body: Stairways serving bulkhead enclosures, not part of the required building egress, providing access from the outside grade level to the basement shall be exempt from the requirements of Sections 311.3 and 311.7 where the height from the basement finished floor level to grade adjacent to the stairway is not more than 8 feet (2438 mm) and the grade level opening to the stairway is covered by a bulkhead enclosure with hinged doors or other approved means.

diagrams.title: Bulkhead Enclosures
diagrams.descriptionHtml: A bulkhead enclosure provides a secure and weather-resistant exit from the basement to the outside of a building. The stairways serving bulkhead enclosures are not part of the required primary means of escape. The maximum height from the basement finished floor level to the finished ground level adjacent to the stairway must not exceed 8 ft.

children.body:
Alternating tread devices shall not be used as an element of a means of egress. Alternating tread devices shall be permitted provided that a required means of egress stairway or ramp serves the same space at each adjoining level or where a means of egress is not required. The clear width at and below the handrails shall be not less than 20 inches (508 mm).
Exception: Alternating tread devices are allowed to be used as an element of a means of egress for lofts, mezzanines and similar areas of 200 gross square feet (18.6 m2) or less where such devices do not provide exclusive access to a kitchen or bathroom.

diagrams.title: Alternating Tread Devices
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Alternating tread devices may not be used as a required means of egress. An alternating tread device may be provided in addition to a compliant required means of egress. There is an exception for spaces such as lofts, mezzanines and other similar areas less than or equal to 200 gross square feet that do not contain a kitchen or a bathroom that allows an alternating tread device to be an element of the means of egress.

children.body: Alternating tread devices shall have a tread depth of not less than 5 inches (127 mm), a projected tread depth of not less than 8<sup>1</sup>/<sub>2</sub> inches (216 mm), a tread width of not less than 7 inches (178 mm) and a riser height of not more than 9<sup>1</sup>/<sub>2</sub> inches (241 mm). The tread depth shall be measured horizontally between the vertical planes of the foremost projections of adjacent treads. The riser height shall be measured vertically between the leading edges of adjacent treads. The riser height and tread depth provided shall result in an angle of ascent from the horizontal of between 50 and 70 degrees (0.87 and 1.22 rad). The initial tread of the device shall begin at the same elevation as the platform, landing or floor surface.
children.displayTitle: R311.7.11.1 Treads of Alternating Tread Devices

children.body: Handrails shall be provided on both sides of alternating tread devices and shall comply with Sections 311.7.8.2 to 311.7.8.6. Handrail height shall be uniform, not less than 30 inches (762 mm) and not more than 34 inches (864 mm).
children.displayTitle: R311.7.11.2 Handrails of Alternating Tread Devices

children.body:
Ships ladders shall not be used as an element of a means of egress. Ships ladders shall be permitted provided that a required means of egress stairway or ramp serves the same space at each adjoining level or where a means of egress is not required. The clear width at and below the handrails shall be not less than 20 inches (508 mm).
Exception: Ships ladders are allowed to be used as an element of a means of egress for lofts, mezzanines and similar areas of 200 gross square feet (18.6 m2) or less that do not provide exclusive access to a kitchen or bathroom.

diagrams.title: Ship's Ladders (Residential)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Ship's ladders may not be used as a required means of egress. A ship's ladder may be provided in addition to a compliant required means of egress. There is an exception for spaces such as lofts, mezzanines and other similar areas less than or equal to 200 gross square feet that do not contain a kitchen or a bathroom that allows for a ship's ladder to be an element of the means of egress.

children.body: Treads shall have a depth of not less than 5 inches (127 mm). The tread shall be projected such that the total of the tread depth plus the nosing projection is not less than 8<sup>1</sup>/<sub>2</sub> inches (216 mm). The riser height shall be not more than 9<sup>1</sup>/<sub>2</sub> inches (241 mm).
children.displayTitle: R311.7.12.1 Treads of Ship's Ladders

children.body: Handrails shall be provided on both sides of ships ladders and shall comply with Sections 311.7.8.2 to 311.7.8.6. Handrail height shall be uniform, not less than 30 inches (762 mm) and not more than 34 inches (864 mm).
children.displayTitle: R311.7.12.2 Handrails of Ship's Ladders

diagrams.title: Glazing Next to Stairs and Ramps (IRC)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Glazing adjacent to stairs and ramps shall be considered to be in a hazardous location and required safety glazing materials. Safety glazing materials, including but not limited to tempered glass, laminated glass, wire glass or rigid plastic, are used in hazardous locations where the potential for human impact can lead to serious injuries.

diagrams.title: Vertical Egress
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Habitable levels and habitable attic levels that do not have an egress door shall be provided with vertical egress to an exit. Where required, the vertical egress shall be by a ramp in compliance with R311.8 or by a stairway in compliance with R311.7.

children.body: Ramps serving the egress door required by Section 311.2 shall have a slope of not more than 1 unit vertical in 8 units horizontal (12.5-percent slope).

There shall be a floor or landing at the top and bottom of each ramp, where doors open onto ramps, and where ramps change directions. The width of the landing perpendicular to the ramp slope shall be not less than 36 inches (914 mm).
Handrails shall be provided on not less than one side of ramps exceeding a slope of one unit vertical in 12 units horizontal (8.33-percent slope).

diagrams.title: Type I Handrail Profile (Res.)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Type I handrails are either circular with a cross section that has an outside diameter between 1-1/4" to 2" maximum. When the handrail is not circular, then it needs to have a perimeter that is between 4" to 6-1/4" maximum with a cross section that is not greater than 2-1/4". The edges of non-circular handrail can have a radius of 0.01" minimum.

children.body: Handrail height, measured above the finished surface of the ramp slope, shall be not less than 34 inches (864 mm) and not more than 38 inches (965 mm).
Handrails on ramps shall comply with Section 311.7.8.5.

diagrams.title: Type I Handrail Profile (Res.)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Type I handrails are either circular with a cross section that has an outside diameter between 1-1/4" to 2" maximum. When the handrail is not circular, then it needs to have a perimeter that is between 4" to 6-1/4" maximum with a cross section that is not greater than 2-1/4". The edges of non-circular handrail can have a radius of 0.01" minimum.

children.body: Handrails where required on ramps shall be continuous for the full length of ramp. Handrail ends shall return or shall terminate in newel posts or safety terminals. Handrails adjacent to a wall shall have a space of not less than 11/2-inches (38 mm) between the wall and the handrails.

children.displayTitle: Section R312 Guards and Window Fall Protection

children.body: Guards shall be provided in accordance with Sections 312.1.1 through 312.1.4.

diagrams.title: Example: Residential Deck Guards
diagrams.descriptionHtml: According to the residential code, a guard is a building component or a system of building components located near the open sides of elevated walking surfaces that minimizes the possibility of a fall from the walking surface to the lower level. The minimum required height for guards at open-sided walking surfaces shall be not less than 36 inches as measured vertically above the adjacent walking surface.

children.body:
Guards shall be provided for those portions of open-sided walking surfaces, including stairs, ramps and landings, that are located more than 30 inches (762 mm) measured vertically to the floor or grade below at any point within 36 inches (914 mm) horizontally to the edge of the open side. Insect screening shall not be considered as a guard.
Exception: Guards are not required where a protective bar is installed 34 inches to 38 inches (864 mm to 965 mm) above the porch or deck on the interior side of the screening. The protective bar shall be capable of resisting a horizontal load of 50 pounds per lineal foot (730 N/m) without contacting the screen and be a minimum of 11/2 inches (38 mm) in height.

diagrams.title: Guards:  Connection Requirements
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
ASCE 7 requires the 200 pound load to be placed in any direction at any point on the handrail or top rail to produce a maximum load effect. This would mean a load pulling on the rail inward would create a maximum tension on the bottom bolt, but a 200 pound force outward (typically associated with "falling" outward) would put the maximum tension on the top bolt.

However, the Residential Code, in Table R301.5, footnote d, states: "A single concentrated load applied in any direction at any point along the top. For a guard not required to serve as a handrail, the load need not be applied to the top element of the guard in a direction parallel to such element." This language does not seem to appear in ASCE 7 at this time.

Therefore, the designer should consider providing tension resisting hardware on both bolts, or consider an alternate design. Simply relying on the rim board would put the member into cross-grain bending, which has considerably lower strength than the beam itself.

diagrams.title: Residential Guards
diagrams.descriptionHtml: GUARD. A building component or a system of building components located near the open sides of elevated walking surfaces that minimizes the possibility of a fall from the walking surface to the lower level.

children.body:
Required guards at open-sided walking surfaces, including stairs, porches, balconies or landings, shall be not less than 36 inches (914 mm) in height as measured vertically above the adjacent walking surface or the line connecting the nosings.
Exceptions:
  1. Guards on the open sides of stairs shall have a height of not less than 34 inches (864 mm) measured vertically from a line connecting the nosings.
  2. Where the top of the guard serves as a handrail on the open sides of stairs, the top of the guard shall be not less than 34 inches (864 mm) and not more than 38 inches (965 mm) as measured vertically from a line connecting the nosings.

diagrams.title: Example: Residential Deck Guards
diagrams.descriptionHtml: According to the residential code, a guard is a building component or a system of building components located near the open sides of elevated walking surfaces that minimizes the possibility of a fall from the walking surface to the lower level. The minimum required height for guards at open-sided walking surfaces shall be not less than 36 inches as measured vertically above the adjacent walking surface.

diagrams.title: Handrail Height
diagrams.descriptionHtml: A handrail is required on at least one side of all flights of stairs exceeding 3 risers. Handrail height along flights of stairs is measured from the imaginary plane or planes defined by the stairway's tread nosing. The code calls for handrails to be from 34 to 38 inches in height. Though not specifically noted in the code, handrail height should be consistent along each flight of stairs. The code allows for the rail height to exceed 38" at continuous transitions, typically called "goosenecks", that take place at between flights of stairs, winder treads, and where the handrail transitions from a stair handrail to a guard. Over the lowest tread, the code also allows for the handrail height to be lower than 34" or taller than 38" for a volute, turnout or starting easing.

children.body:
Required guards shall not have openings from the walking surface to the required guard height that allow passage of a sphere 4 inches (102 mm) in diameter.
Exceptions:
  1. The triangular openings at the open side of stair, formed by the riser, tread and bottom rail of a guard, shall not allow passage of a sphere 6 inches (153 mm) in diameter.
  2. Guards on the open side of stairs shall not have openings that allow passage of a sphere 43/8 inches (111 mm) in diameter.

diagrams.title: Example: Residential Deck Guards
diagrams.descriptionHtml: According to the residential code, a guard is a building component or a system of building components located near the open sides of elevated walking surfaces that minimizes the possibility of a fall from the walking surface to the lower level. The minimum required height for guards at open-sided walking surfaces shall be not less than 36 inches as measured vertically above the adjacent walking surface.

children.body: Plastic composite exterior guards shall comply with the requirements of Section 317.4.
When provided, window fall protection shall be in accordance with Sections 312.2.1 and 312.2.2.
Window fall prevention devices and window guards, where provided, shall comply with the requirements of ASTM F2090.
children.displayTitle: R312.2.1 Window Sills Fall Prevention Devices
children.titleText: Window Sills Fall Prevention Devices

children.body: Where provided, window opening limiting devices shall comply with the provisions of this section.
children.displayTitle: R312.2.2 Window Opening Control Limiting Devices
children.titleText: Window Opening Control Limiting Devices

children.body: Window opening limiting devices shall be self-acting and shall be positioned to prohibit the free passage of a 4-in. (102-mm) diameter rigid sphere through the window opening when the window opening limiting device is installed in accordance with the manufacturer's instructions.

Window opening limiting devices shall be designed with release mechanisms to allow for emergency escape through the window opening without the need for keys, tools or special knowledge. Window opening limiting devices shall comply with all of the following:
  1. Release of the window opening-limiting device shall require no more than 15 pounds (66 N) of force.
  2. The window opening limiting device release mechanism shall operate properly in all types of weather.
  3. Window opening limiting devices shall have their release mechanisms clearly identified for proper use in an emergency.
  4. The window opening limiting device shall not reduce the minimum net clear opening area of the window unit below what is required by Section 310.1.1 of the code.

diagrams.title: Fire Protection of Floors (IRC)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Floor assemblies not required elsewhere in the code to be fire-resistance rated, are required to be protected as follows. Membrane floor protection must be placed on the underside of the floor framing members and may be 1/2-inch gypsum wallboard, 5/8-inch wood structural panel membrane, or an approved equivalent material. Floor assembly protection is not required for a floor located directly over a space protected by an automatic sprinkler system. Where the floor assembly is located directly over a crawl space and the crawl space and will not contain any fuel-burning or electric appliance and will not be utilized for storage, protection of the floor assembly is not required. Protection of the floor assembly is not required where portions of the aggregate area(s) of the unprotected portion(s) of the floor assembly in a story do not exceed 80 square feet and the perimeter of the unprotected portion(s) are separated from the protected portions of the floor assembly by fireblocking. Floor protection may be omitted where the floor assembly relies on 2x10 nominal or larger lumber, composite lumber or is of equivalent fire performance.

children.displayTitle: Section R313 Automatic Fire Sprinkler Systems

children.body: An automatic residential fire sprinkler system is not required to be installed in buildings with four or more dwelling units or other Group R occupancies permitted to use this code.

diagrams.title: Dwelling Unit Fire Sprinkler Systems: Coverage Area
diagrams.descriptionHtml: To ensure that an automatic sprinkler fire suppression system provides adequate coverage the code limits how much area each sprinkler head may be responsible for covering to 400 sf or as prescribed in the manufacturer's installation instructions for the sprinkler head based on its listing, whichever is less.

children.displayTitle: R313.1 Townhouse Dwelling Unit Automatic Fire Sprinkler Systems
children.titleText: Townhouse Dwelling Unit Automatic Fire Sprinkler Systems

children.body: When a non-required automatic residential fire sprinkler system is intended to be installed within a building with four or more dwelling units or a dwelling in another R-3 occupancy using this code, the system shall be designed and installed in accordance with Section 2904, NFPA 13, NFPA 13R or NFPA 13D as referenced in Chapter 44 of this code.
children.displayTitle: R313.1.1 Design and Installation for Non-Required Systems
children.titleText: Design and Installation for Non-Required Systems

children.body: An automatic residential fire sprinkler system is not required to be installed in one-, two-, or three-family dwellings.
children.displayTitle: R313.2 One-, And Two- And Three-Family Dwellings Automatic Fire Sprinkler Systems
children.titleText: One-, And Two- And Three-Family Dwellings Automatic Fire Sprinkler Systems

children.body: When an automatic residential fire sprinkler system is intended to be installed, it shall be designed and installed in accordance with Section 2904, NFPA 13, NFPA 13R or NFPA 13D as referenced in Chapter 44 of this code.
children.displayTitle: R313.2.1 Design and Installation for Non-Required Systems
children.titleText: Design and Installation for Non-Required Systems

children.body: Any full or partial fire sprinkler system not required by this code shall be permitted to be installed for partial or complete protection provided that such system meets the requirements of this code to the extent of the intended installation.
children.displayTitle: 313.3 Design and Installation of Non-Required Fire Sprinkler Systems
children.titleText: Design and Installation of Non-Required Fire Sprinkler Systems

children.body: Smoke alarms shall comply with the household fire warning equipment provisions of NFPA 72 and Section 314.
Smoke alarms shall be listed and labeled in accordance with UL 217. Combination smoke and carbon monoxide alarms shall be listed and labeled in accordance with UL 217 and UL 2034.

On each level within each dwelling unit smoke alarms utilizing photoelectric and ionization technologies shall be installed. Separate or dual-sensing smoke alarms may be used. A smoke alarm located in accordance with Section 314.3(2) shall include photoelectric technology.

Exception: A system meeting the requirements of Section 314.7 is not required to include both technologies.
Smoke alarms shall be provided in accordance with this section.
Smoke alarms shall be provided in dwelling units in the locations described in Section 314.3.

Where alterations, repairs or additions requiring an approval occur, smoke alarms shall be installed, as required for new construction, as follows:
  1. When alterations or repairs are made to spaces described in items 1 and 2 of Section 314.3, smoke alarms shall be provided in those areas.
  2. When one or more sleeping rooms are added to or created in existing dwelling units, the new sleeping rooms and the immediate vicinity outside each sleeping room shall be equipped with smoke alarms.
Exceptions:
  1. Work involving the exterior surfaces of dwellings, such as the replacement of roofing or siding, the addition or replacement of windows or doors, or the addition of a porch or deck.
  2. Installation, alteration or repairs of plumbing or mechanical systems.

Smoke alarms shall be installed in the following locations:
